pros: Excellent care about the students
cons: Close down the school every location

pros: Good company for career college for any age
cons: It shut down before almost students graduation

pros: Flexible hours of needed medically.
cons: Did not focus on student but rather money!

pros: Virginia College has good benefits
cons: Virginia College's work life balance was horrible.

pros: Being able to meet students
cons: Putting the students in too much debt

review_title: Was the best until it wasn't
pros: they work with you to assure you get your personal time
cons: they are always changing things last minute

pros: good co-workers supportive and fun
cons: poor management from upper level admin.

pros: Enjoyed working with the students and making an impact on their lives.
cons: No stability in employment knowing the plan was to close the technical college.

pros: The flexibility in my work schedule and the team I worked with
cons: The corporate office making education changes without having anyone with a education background. The mismanagement of money and people.

review_title: Virginia College Could Have Been a Great Workplace!
pros: Management was not trained well
cons: Some people do all the work.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Great administration and upper management
cons: Academically unprepared and un-motivated students

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Birmingham, AL
pros: The starting salary was reasonable, and you did get to help some students.
cons: They would pressure you to commit fraud and apply "placements" to jobs that definitely didn't qualify. Admissions took in students with criminal histories that made careers in their degree programs nearly impossible, so they would pressure you to find similar job tasks in unrelated work to gain a "success story."

review_title: Went Bankrupt and screwed lots of people!
pros: I enjoyed the student population
cons: Cheaters, thieves, lied to the students.

job_title: Student Finance Support Specialist in Birmingham, AL
pros: Changing students lives. Great coworkers.
cons: Pay your SF Team at the campus. Paying us low 30s is a joke and 2k raises every year is not going to retain the hard working SF Specialist that goes above and beyond, making sure A/R is low and students are packaged in a timely manner.  We are a team, but Admissions pay is way more than Student Finance. How are you going to cap us out at the low 40s and cap Admissions at 60+ when Student Finance gives referrals, works in retention, do Student Accounts duties, package students, act as bill collectors, to name a few. We do it all and can barely afford to pay rent. Yet you want us to work on saturdays and not let us request vacation, because of all the blackout days. You will hire someone outside the company, but not promote someone who knows the process, how to do the job and who's been at the company for 3+ years.

job_title: Student Finance Representative in Birmingham, AL
pros: Co-Workers were like family; great work environment
cons: Salary was too low for the amount of work.

pros: Building clean, and someone dressed up as security (no firearm) is always there.  Good facilities.
cons:
Students should do a thorough search of where they could spend their educational $ and more than  likely this one would not be in the top ten.  Quality knowledgeable administration is lacking in most areas and what goes on in the classroom, other getting them to attend, is pretty much down played.  Total focus is keeping live bodies enrolled so that the $ will continue to flow.  Things that might get you expelled in high school may be overlooked here.  Instructor pay is barely above minimum wage, if he/she are  good instructors who do the proper prep for the class. Some faculty seems to be weak, some teaching classes where they have never had experience in areas they are teaching, especially little outside the class room. 
My suggestion is for potential students to keep looking and potential instructors get a part time minimum wage job in a better environment.

pros: You are paid well but you will have to work nights and weekend
cons: they place will make you sell your soul for an enrollment

pros: Virginia College (owned by ECA (Education Corporation of America) overall is a very fair employer in terms of zero tolerance against racisim; so far in two years of employment I have not experienced any reverse or forward discrimination; nor any inappropriate focus on religion as can seem to happen in the Southern work force. I enjoy helping people learn; and I do love my field; these are the primary reasons I accepted the job.
cons: There is however a preponderance of industrial based policy making; no doubt driven by a "Soft Drink" imported top management team. ECA is therefore more profit driven then other higher learning institutions such as community colleges or non-profit colleges and universities. However, I would say in many instances this focus on profit does bring a focus back on the customer (in this case the student) so that satisfaction is ensured. The mandatory company goal of exceeding it's accreditor's 60% compliance metric in employment placement to instead focus on a goal of meeting a 72% placement rate, definitely operates as a check and balance that the customer (student) is getting what they're paying out the nose for.  As well as ensures complete and total burnout of their underpaid Career Services and Academic adjunct teaching staff. Ah, the nature of "for profit learning"- what a beast...gotta love it.

pros: the pay and benefits were good
cons: The campus president and his unwanted harassment

review_title: If you aspire to mediocrity, this is your place!
pros: I sat here for 30 minutes trying to come up with positive things to say about Virginia College and this is the only positive thing I can think of: " 20% of the student population genuinely appreciates the staff's help".
cons:
Enrollment: 60 % of students do not qualify to start college or diploma programs; cannot spell, cannot type, are not literate, cannot complete simple math equations, are not committed to the process of changing their lives, are not professional enough to conduct themselves appropriately in school/ college
Academics: a machine that swallows students, always coddling and holding their hands, pushing them through the necessary motions to "graduate" .
Final Product: an uneducated, unskilled, unprofessional mass, many with a criminal history, PTSD etc., unfit to enter the labor market.
Placement Services: trying to place this flawed "final product" at average companies in hopes something will stick. 
Atmosphere on campus: a bunch of stressed, overworked, unappreciated ants working in semi-unison to assist, enable, and prevent the "bottom of the barrel student mass" from quitting school at all cost.

pros: Most instructors are very knowledgeable in their field, flexible hours, mid-level management is reasonable and accommodating, building and facility is new and top-notch
cons:
1. Upper level management on campus totally does not support faculty. 
2.  Overwhelming majority of students are check-chasers
 3.  Due to (apparent) pressure on enrollment to meet quotas, students who lack basic literacy skills are enrolled and placed in programs where their ultimate chances for success are bleak. 
4.  In programs with large female populations such as medical assisting and surg tech, the high rate of student pregnancy necessarily impacts attendance in those programs. When an instructors attendance drops to 85% they are written up, counseled, and placed on an improvement plan. A few quarters ago I had a class with 10 students, all female, two of whom were placed on bed rest the last 4-5 weeks of the quarter due to pregnancy complications. As such I had to develop an instructor improvement plan to improve my attendance. I've been there almost two years and I've had perhaps only 5 male students. Instructors should not be penalized for the reproductive habits of the students.

pros: Employees were great and everyone works hard.
cons: Stu Reed is horrible and Campus Presidents are people who were fired from other schools (horrible!)

job_title: Financial Planning Officer in Montgomery, AL
pros: It's an easy pay check. There is always something to do and you are never bored if you work.
cons: I do not know whether or not I work at a school or a bank sometimes. Students call incessantly about loan proceed money. It's an alternative school for people who either didn't make it at other more reputable colleges or people who never had the motivation to go to a descent college in the first place. Also, the company is highly disorganized. Corporate makes sporadic decisions and then changes them over and over again. If anything goes wrong then it is the Planners fault.  The company is highly blameful. The most harmful quick decision was a system change that affected requesting funds for students. They hastily stopped using a certain company due to bad business relations. Some student's funds could not be requested in the time frame allotted and again, it was the Planner's fault. Lastly, but certainly not least, the school is predatory. Their target market is Black females. They offer degrees and certifications at ridiculous prices. A community college would charge around $2100 for certain certificates, VC charges $22,000 for the same certificate. This is the subprime market for education, for-profit schools.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty Member in Columbia, SC
pros: Instructors can mostly work the hours they want at the times they want. It is a fairly good job for those who are also working another job and need supplemental income.
cons: Serious stress & pressure for the low pay that you get. If you can't get your students to attend, your salary gets reduced the next quarter. Instructors are blamed when students don't come to class. The last term I worked there, I actually had to fill out a daily questionnaire for each class I taught describing what was taught and what I did to make my students want to return to class. The students should have been required to fill out the same questionnaire describing what they did to make me want to return to class. The students were very immature, and I was constantly handling behavioral issues that should have been handled in kindergarten. I resigned because I no longer felt safe. The last term I worked there, I had to call security three times. One of those times, the school called the police and two of my students were arrested for fighting in class. I would advise any instructor who is considering working there to get self-defense training first.

pros: great pay , Flexible Work Schedule , nice perks , students , smiling faces. Great raise in short amount of time. Its like running your own business in the enrollment department. Work as a team when you can. Great chain of command and training when it comes to corporate
cons: Unqualified Management , Horrible System  for gaining enrollment. The job requires a lot of outbound calling because the school is for profit. So as an enrollment specialist you play the job of counselor, recruiter , enroller , academic supervisor ,career service and all. The programs are overpriced so it is hard to sell a product you do not believe in. Great position for business majors , specifically  marketing. Out of 100 phone calls you may get 1 student on the phone interested in enrolling. And out of that one student you have to harass them like  bill collector. You have to constantly find something to do.

job_title: Administrative Assistant Cosmo in Birmingham, AL
pros: Pays pretty well & has pretty good benefits.  There are a lot of people that work there or have worked there that are good people.  I loved my co-workers.
cons: They do a lot of laying off and terminating positions that they really need just to save money.  Then they put the duties of the eliminated position on the employees that are still there without giving them any compensation.  They also claim to be student first but in the end it's all about the money.

pros: You have the opportunity to change lives of our students. Curriculum is awesome. The pay is good. There are knowledgeable management. State of the art equipment. Lots of events and activities for our students. The program is short and attainable. The company does a lot for the students. Professional products used. Education is an investment.
cons: Like any place of employment there will always be something that you don't like about the company.  Make the best out of every situation.  The company is only as good as those who are allowed to be in leadership.

pros: Work from anywhere.  Courses are pre-loaded.  Asynchronous online.  Good benefits, up to 6% matching 401k.  Relatively autonomous. Doesn't matter what time of day you want to work.
cons: Quarterly, and not always much of a break between terms - long break between summer and fall, a couple weeks around Christmas/New Years.  Not the greatest pay for the amount of required work, but not the worst, either.  The bottom line is all that seems to matter to corporate, even though they always say student success is most important.  Remember - it's a FOR-PROFIT institution.

job_title: Director of Career Services in Pensacola, FL
pros: It is a good alternative for health care professionals who want to escape a hospital environment.  It provides part time teaching positions in most major college subject areas.  In Pensacola, with few opportunities for college graduates, this may be one of the only opportunities to obtain a job that requires academic skills.
cons: virginia College is a for-profit company.  Management is focused on making a profit and appears not to realize that low employee morale across the entire campus is a problem.  The pay to teach a class is only $600.00.  There is a lot of prep work required outside class time, reports to submit, meetings to attend, etc.  The pay divided by total hours worked is very low.

pros: Instructors & staff genuinely care about the students, instructor to student ratio is low, most instructors work in their respective fields and are able to provide "real-world" experience, hands-on experience (via required externship).
cons: It is very EXPENSIVE! For what I paid, I should have a bachelors degree, but I only have a certificate. They promote themselves as a school for working adults, but they're not accommodating AT ALL! There isn't nearly enough classes offered at varying times to accommodate a working adults schedule. Most fields of study will require an externship to graduate. Completing this, while working a full-time job was very challenging, to say the least.

pros: About the only thing I can think of is pay.
cons: This place is horrible. No care whatsoever for the students or the employees. We have serious issues that happen on campus that are ignored so we can keep that number. No growth. Your job is threatened everyday. There's a large amount of pressure to enroll students who aren't qualified just to make numbers. Management is the worst, really a bunch of bullies. There are so many things wrong with this place and not enough time to write everything. Yeah, work life balance is a whole different issue. Steer clear of this place. You will regret it. This job is only about pleasing the investors.

job_title: Student Finance Specialist in Columbia, SC
pros: The pay is pretty decent and there is an opportunity to encourage, inspire, and in some cases influence others to pursue their dreams.
cons: There is no structure within the organization. Poor leadership. There is no such thing as "student's first" as they advertise. Every entry is a number that they earn or retain by feeding them and giving prizes for attendance. They even enroll the elderly that has no intentions on working, can barely read, and have no clue how to operate computers....but they will now have loan debt.  ECA (corporate) care nothing about employees. They do not listen to them and neither are they there when needed.

pros: The students truly need a compassionate, dedicated, and educated individual in each class room. If that is you, you will be fulfilled. The culture of the campus is pretty comfortable most of the time.
cons: It is a constant revolving door.you never who was going to be terminated.being that its a proprietary school, numbers means everything. Numbers must be good in every department, even if its means not upholding the schools motto, student first.just will like corporate America, management will always do what is in their best interest. Training was inadequate...almost none at all.

pros:
Great place, great people. They want people that are forward thinkers. This is not a college stuck on what has worked for 20 years. They want the faculty to push new ideas and ways. They believe that if the book or lessons are not providing the desired results, the school says it is your job (responsibility) to suggest another way to present the information so the student can use it.  
Personal growth benefits other than pay are top drawer, access to books, courses, testing, and other memberships just to name a few
cons: The pay is not the best, but I an not doing this just for the pay. Local director and Dean do not have much wiggle room on the pay.

pros:
Flexible schedule, benefits, working with students. 
It is difficult to come up with too many 'good' reasons to work for this CORPORATION.
cons:
I have never seen an institution where faculty are so mistreated!
The morale is lower than unbelievably low.
Blame for all of the problems at VC is put on the faculty, and more and more is demanded without raises in pay, or at the very least, praise for a job well done when it is due!
Clearly an institution that is FOR PROFIT and could care less about its faculty.
Faculty are encouraged to have low standards and students have no accountability.
It is an oppressive nightmare---consider carefully working for this CORPORATION (not an educational institution).

job_title: Student Finance Coordinator in Savannah, GA
pros: I love working directly with the students. I am great at my job, and students respond to me well, making it much easier. The people I work with are awesome. The pay is good. My management is awesome, and makes me feel comfortable and confident in my abilities.
cons: Students will enroll despite being notified of a large monthly payment. They don't take it seriously.  There are always updates to our methods, which makes it difficult to maintain the most current information.

pros: None, you are just a Number and it’s a numbers game. They expect you to get students signed into college, and a certain amount a month! However, they are not even accredited right now and hasn’t been since January 2017.
cons: They fire people very quickly. Turnover is high. They interview for Your position why you are in it. Upper management are snakes and you cannot trust them. Definitely an unfair organization. If considering working here, don’t. This is. Shrinking ship and accreditation will be lapsing completely In March 2018 and financial aid will not be available for students then. Do your research!

review_title: RUN DON'T WALK AWAY FROM THIS COLLEGE!!!
pros: There aren't any pros working here.
cons: There is a great divide in departments and it's done on purpose to keep employees from bonding. It's a very cutthroat place to work with a very very high turnover. Don't quit your day job because longevity here is nonexistent. Titles are created for the favored employees and nothing is merit based. The atmosphere is tense and stressful. The goal is only on numbers and pushing students through regardless of attendance, grades, or performance. The ads in the paper are constant and jobs are threatened on a regular basis.

review_title: This is an awful company to work for - parent company of Ecotech Institute
pros: Ecotech is a great place to be if you're really really desperate for a job and you're just using the position here to bide time till you find a different job.
cons: Management & Upper Management is totally incompetent.  It gets worse. They're also arrogant and pretty mean to the average employee who's just trying to do h/her job well.  You're punished for being a proactive employee, because sometimes that means that you've embarrassed someone in upper management who isn't doing h/her job (btw, they're extremely top heavy and all make at least six figures for doing 1/2 the work and taking 1/16th of the responsibility and the accountability that the worker bees have to take).

review_title: VA College used to be good.  No longer.
pros: There are still some good staff left over from the earlier days when things were done right.
cons: The new senior management has shifted the focus from caring for the students to only producing income.  As a result the student population has decreased and the professional preparation  provided by the school is poor.  This is not a good place to work.  The senior management is untrustworthy and the Campus Presidents are often just reacting to fear based management techniques.  They don't care about the staff or the students.  Its sad and not productive, but VA College has probably slipped to the point where their reputation in the market could not rebound.  I would not recommend anyone I cared about working here.

review_title: Working hard to become to world leader of post secondary education !
pros: Great atmosphere. Do your job. Performance is rewarded. I love the competitiveness! I appreciate ECA working hard to get their good name back. They are doing it right.
cons: Sometimes people aren't trained well enough before they "go live" if you want it standardized through out the company- have a training class for the new employee in the specific department they work in to do it the ECA way.

job_title: Enrollment Specialist in Bossier City, LA
pros: Great" initial" corporate training, supportive and friendly coworkers, scheduled events to recognize employee achievements, great pay! Very involved in the community and employees are expected to participate. Great company if you are already experienced and can bring in tons of your own referrals. Having a 'thick skin" will be helpful when dealing with management's egos.
cons: Very stressful if you don't "drink the koolaid" . Management can really play favorites and it is often a "Do as I say, not as I do"  environment which creates confusion and double standards.

pros: None, none, none, none, none, none, none , none, none, none,none, none, none, none, none none none none none none none
cons: Where do I begin? Student First?? Please!!! They are bottom feeders!!!! The campus president and other campus leaders are as crooked as they come. Corporate knows what goes no but doesn't care. As long as the big$$$$$'s are coming in, they could care less.... Have you heard of slave labor?? Work you to death and if they can't make their enrollment numbers... See you... It's your fault the student didn't enroll, attend it stay

pros:
great students
some good teachers
nice campus
graduation is planned out wonderfully
cons:
deceitful
Watch your financial aid money
tuition is too high
untrusting management on campus
Dishonest
Manipulative

pros: Virginia College is a family atmosphere and a great place to work as well as to advance if you are interested in advancement.  Very student focused and encourages employee satisfaction.
cons: Communication between departments.  This the only downside I have ever found working for this company.  Sometimes decisions are made  which affect your department but you are not aware of the decisions.

review_title: Good company that lost it's way
pros:
- Opportunity to assist others in making an education dream come true.
- Decent pay for the position
- Decent compensation package including PTO
- Continuing education opportunities for employees
- Can make this a meaningful career if you are able to survive the yearly layoffs.
- Met and worked with many different individuals that have become lifelong friends.
cons:
- Lack of job security due to yearly layoffs, closing of multiple schools.
- Once the current CEO took over, most of management became reactive instead of being proactive, although this seemed to change once the company was denied (twice) by the ACCET accrediting body. With ACICS re-accreditation looming, they have learned their lesson (I hope) and are going back to basics of being proactive when it comes to compliance.
- Senior Management (Home office aka. Corporate) would roll out constant changes but not communicate to their peers at the top. The lack of communication led to many conflicting policies that created a lot of confusion at the campus level that ultimately affected the student and employees at the campus.
- While most positions where well compensated, constant layoffs/eliminating crucial positions had many individuals picking up the pieces of other departments and doing the work of 2, 3, or 4 people.
- Work Life Balance takes a major hit, especially if you are at the management level.
- Hourly employees are pressured to complete 50-60 hour work responsibilities into 40 hours because OT is not approved.
- Constant budget cuts due to declining enrollment.

pros: In my department, students were very focused and serious about their new careers.  Dedicated instructors that saw to the advancement of those students willing to put forth the effort to learn.
cons: Corporate leaders were not educators.  Focused on being the largest for-profit college and lost sight of their "students first" effort.  Poor management at the top of the organization.  No pay increases over the last 5 years.

pros: The best reasons to work here is to attempt to help the students and the people that you meet.
cons: The company will hire people with promises of advancement which never materialize; it is standard practice and happens all the time. You work with great students who have goals however with such big course loads and such little time to work with or even meet with any of your students faculty members, specifically part time do not even have a place to meet with or provide counsel for students. The money making philosophy allows for classrooms to be vacated ASAP after class to prepare for an incoming instructors and therefore if a student from the class needs help or has questions, as an adjunct, you must talk with your students as you walk down the hall to the next class. The school is modeled to place numbers ahead of student needs. They also retain students who should be dropped for missing so many classes unexcused just to maintain their retention numbers. It looks good on the bottom line however it is bad practice to have a rule in place and in turn have faculty scolded when the students fails in the end. This school is all about numbers and the bottom line. Many of the instructors are hired at the last moment to teach and many have no previous teaching experience. They must hire this way in that the faculty turnover rate at the college is extremely high, good instructors do not stay. There  is a great deal of pressure placed on faculty members each when student drops or have absences from class, no matter what the reason for the absence or drop. There is also so much work that must be done outside the classroom for part time faculty, it really amounts to full time work plus, and the pay for part time in no way compensates part time faculty who must work over weekends and late most nights to go home grade papers and prepare for classes, the pay is poor, below minimum wage for the amount of work that has to be done outside the classroom to include reports.

pros: Very fair to employees regarding time off, working with personnel to accommodate personal needs.  Pretty good benefits. Generally nice management locally and at corporate level.  Gave good training in the various jobs.
cons: Salaries were not standardized company wide, so lower paying areas of the country got lower pay than others in the same company for the same job.

pros:
lots of good instructors
hands on training
lots of experience among the staff, i keep going to them for advic, even now
lots of poteinal growth
cons:
the cosmetology department is treated separate from the rest of teh school. almost nothing is relevant to us when it comes to the job fairs and mock interviews
constant change in curriculum and policies, often right during the mod 
ridiculous tuition, we pay for in campus housing when there is none

the career department is no help getting a job. stick to the instructors

pros: Decent pay and watching people become professionals when they complete a program is rewarding.
cons: The hours are long. Metrics can be very difficult to attain since its based off of people starting and staying in school. A lot of the students enrolled work full-time, have families, and don't have transportation back and forth to school. Be willing to generate your own leads and if goals aren't met, be ready for a verbal "beating" from management. Don't get it wrong, this job is equivalent to an outside sales position.

pros: Helping to change peoples lives every day by giving them the tools necessary to be successful.  The programs we offer are to not only better the student but better their enviroments.
cons: The largest draw back or misconception of Virginia College is that since we are a for profit school that we do not care about the students we serve.  This misconception has brought on some negative backlash, but I feel if you ask any of the recent grads about their experience at VC and they will tell you that every student truly counts.

review_title: They have a very high turnover and do not protect their employees.
pros: The pay was decent compared to working in the field.
cons: The dean of the school would make very degrading comments.  He would be okay at one minute and yelling the next minute.  He based hiring on the way someone looks when it came to females.  They did not get accredited in a timely fashion so that the students were able to become certified.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Fort Pierce, FL
pros: The pay is pretty good, and it increases every 6 months to a year. You get holidays off and a good amount of paid days off.
cons: You're pretty much selling a $35k+  wortrh of education to students in poor areas knowing good and well they're going to get maybe a $12-14 an hour job. It's not a commission based job but you do have to enroll a certain amount of students per semester. They try to make it seem like they care about the students but they're really just a number.

pros: Great people to work with and getting to know the students really well. The salary was really good and you got paid extra if you took the students to field trips. Great experience to put on resume.
cons: I didn't get hours promised to me. In fear of losing job due to students not showing up or being late to class will affect your work performance even if it is not your fault.

pros: Pay is great, but short-term
cons: Incompetent educational and employment environment. Please do your research on proprietary education before involving yourself in an education or dead-end career at this so-called "school". Management at Charleston, SC campus recruitment dept. is extremely unprofessional and lacking managerial skills. The individual was utilized for this position for their ability to relocate from state to state on a whim. Very insecure and threatened of those around her with skill.

pros: The company overall is a great place to work.
cons:
The local management at the Knoxville campus is highly UNethical.
They are much more concerned about making money than the success of the students

pros: The teachers are very committed to helping and teaching to these students.
cons: Top staff is incompetent to know how to support upper level professionals.

review_title: Not the best company to work for
job_title: Financial Planning Officer in Birmingham, AL
pros:
Helping students get into school 
Good Salaries 
Great benefits
cons:
Company very disorganized 
The tuition for the students is way to expensive 
Has a high tunover rate due to the disorganization and the schedules 
Unfortunetly the company doesn't realize that there is a life outside of those walls and some people do have kids and family they would love to spend time with

pros: The pay was good starting out and the increase was great at six months, but at times not worth it.
cons:
The stress was high and upper management at that time was ruthless. It created a hostile work environment. They started out giving you a good amount of vacation days, but shortly after signing on they changed their policy, which made it difficult to take or earn vacation time. When I got hired on, they were ramping up to increase staff and had the willingness to promote.

Shortly after, the opposite happened and massive firings began. I am not sure how we were held to a weekly quota as a for-profit school.

pros: Great students and they do have some staff members that care about the students instead of a paycheck.
cons: The staff members are not professional for the most part. You have people in positions who have never had experience in education but they are head of departments/Dean.

pros: Great school spirit. I really enjoyed working with the students. The director did everything she could to help the students and staff uphold policies and be their for the students.
cons: I hated the politics of the company. It was very hard to uphold the schools attendance policy. It was unreasonable to make student not miss a minute of class.

pros: The people who work and attend VC are well intentioned and some are highly motivated. I was fortunate to teach students essentially tabula rasa.
cons: The program is a terrible rip off for the students, who do not understand the value they are receiving for the debt incurred.

pros:
-Most instructors care about student education
-Professionalism is strongly emphasized
Facilities/equipment/supplies are decent
cons:
-Pay is slightly low
-Student population/metrics (for financial aid) trump quality of education
-Students aren't always held to the standards/rules (exceptions are made to keep "bad' students enrolled to keep "the numbers" from going below acceptable limits)
-Administration backs students rather than Instructors

review_title: I've worked for three other career colleges. Virgina College takes care of their employees
job_title: Senior Admissions Representative in Austin, TX
pros: Motivating team environment,  provides necessary resources to be successful, pay and benefits are very competitive
cons: Morning a lot of Saturdays  (admissions) and 2 late nights per week

review_title: Virginia College is a fast past, friendly, learning environment that offers ample training and room for growth.
pros: Virginia College is full of professional students, staff and colleagues. There is plenty of room for growth and opportunity from within and abroad the college itself.
cons: Because of the nature of Virginia College being a school there is a strict adherence to proper dress and mannerism.

review_title: Students are NOT chips and sodas
pros: Making a difference in a students life.
cons: Where to start?...The motto of this company is "Student First." This is true until finances play a part. This company has had three reorganizations in two years. Taking registrars off campus and replacing them with incompetent staff at corporate, and taking a program and placing it under the supervision of someone that does not have the credentials.. This is for the betterment of the student. Maybe those that sit in the Ivory tower known as ECA should get off their rear ends drive to a campus and find out what really happens at a school. One quarter tuition goes up the next quarter it goes down.. These are human beings that pay your salary...quit treating them as if they were chips in sodas. ECA managers have never set foot in school they all came from the chips and soda factories. Management at the local campus will lie to the students and employees. With so much change for the students each and every day it's a wonder the schools stay open. Students are forced to take online classes because the dean forces PRogram directors to cancel classes. Dean even went so far as to ask one PD to offer a class to new students in the directed study format just to meet a section bidet. This is against policy. They allow students to enroll that cannot read and can barely write. Adjunct instructors get paid 1200-1500 per class but are forced to put more than 40 hours a week into a class. If the Dean and president do not like an instructor even though they are a good instructor, they will find a way to get rid of them. Dean and president talks about instructors inability to teach even though neither have set foot in the classroom. PD are forced to work more than 40 hours a week, and are expected to teach a minimum of three classes...sometimes more. I would not recommend this company to Satan.

review_title: The company has transformed into a deceitful, unpredictable place of employment.
pros: The pay for a teaching position is enticing until you realize how much work is involved for one hour of class time.
cons: The students are being robbed of up to $40,000 for an Associate's Degree that only ensures a student a post graduation pay rate of $10 per hour. That is the best case scenerio if the student is able to obtain a job after graduation.

pros: The program directors and upper management  where great  they care about team building and student total support.  I enjoyed my job.
cons: Turnovers with upper management, layoffs and quarterly raises went to yearly merits

review_title: Virginia College - Barely Legal, Not Recognized Accreditation, and Preys on the Poor
pros: The pay starting off in Admissions is certainly appealing, and moving up after only 6 months is great. However, good luck making it to that point. Insurance is good, receive it after 30 days.
cons: Where to begin? An Admissions Associate is a salesperson, bottom line. An average day, you will be calling your new leads as well as old leads who have already told you they are not interested yet management will continue to give you the same call sheets. You will be given a budget that is completely unreasonable, and you will most likely have a guilty conscience when you enroll citizens who have no business in higher education, and now as students, they will most likely not complete the degree and be saddled with extreme debt. Few programs at the college are a good investment (culinary, nursing, respiratory tech,  and ultrasound seem to be the only exceptions, and are still expensive). If you decided to accept this job, be warned. To meet your budget, you will have to live your job, be passing out cards on your off time, and constantly stressing. Then when you do earn your promotions and move up, you will find a point where the budget is too high and the company will let you go. In my 4 months there, I believe our Admissions department of roughly 20 saw about half the staff get fired or leave willingly, and as I left, more were also on their way out.

pros:
the coworkers. 
witnessing the moment that a student realizes that she is capable
assisting a well informed student on her career path
cons:
As with most for-profit educational institutions, the stated goal is to provide educational opportunities to those that would not necessarily thrive in a traditional academic setting. In practice, the primary goal is "numbers". It is difficult for the company to balance its demand for revenue with its desire to "transform lives".  Admissions reps are encouraged to get only quality applicants, but are berated for not having enough students enrolled. This unfortunately leads admissions reps to adopt questionable admissions practices, including lying and enrolling unqualified students. 
The school where I worked was located in an impoverished community. The lure of stipends was very enticing to potential students. Some students admittedly only attended to receive what little loan money was left over after paying for their tuition. This is an area of great concern. The students that do graduate with a certificate or an associate degree (as many do not) can expect to have approximately $20k in loan debt and a low wage job. 
Tuition is excessive, but this is due in part to the amount of staff required to create an extremely personalized (to the point of coddling) experience for the students. Setting the tone, admissions contacts a prospective student multiple times a day for several days if she misses an appointment. If her financial aid on hold she is called and emailed repeatedly and if this fails she is escorted from her class to the financial aid office to take care of her responsibilities. Every time a student misses a class she is called. This technique may be effective initially to demonstrate concern and provide encouragement especially to those who haven’t had the benefit of a nurturing home life. But here the student is never allowed to show initiative or be self-reliant which is detrimental to development and future career prospects. Virginia College’s mission is sound, but its practices are injurious to the students it claims to put first.

pros:

Students are motivated
cons: Pay is average, and they spread each quarter's contract over the time from the first day of class to the following quarter start.  So you still get paid between quarters, but the amount can vary from quarter to quarter, depending on how many weeks are open between quarters.  Hard to budget.
